clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound Guided vs Unguided Intra-articular Knee Injections
clinical_study.official_title: Accuracy of Ultrasound Guided Versus Unguided Intra-articular Knee Injections in a Difficult to Inject Population

brief_summary.textblock: To determine the accuracy of unguided versus ultrasound (US) guided knee joint injections in obese patients with no clinically detectable effusion.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of the initial needle placement into the knee joint.
primary_outcome.time_frame: During the initial needle placement, which can take 1-5 minutes
primary_outcome.description: The number of participants with accurate initial needle placement into the knee joint

secondary_outcome.measure: Improved clinical efficacy of US guided knee injections compared to unguided knee injections
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of VAS scores 30 minutes after injection between subjects who had ultrasound guided knee injections and those who didn't

other_outcome.time_frame: During procedure, which can take up to 30 minutes to complete
other_outcome.description: Comparison of the accuracy of detecting a knee effusion on clinical examination versus ultrasonographically

arm_group.description: Use of ultrasound machine guidance in needle placement into the knee joint
Needle placement performed without ultrasound machine guidance

intervention.description: Use of ultrasound machine guidance for accurate needle placement into the knee joint
Needle placement will take place without ultrasound machine guidance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- BMI > 30
- No clinically detectable knee effusion
- Clinical or radiographic evidence of knee osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis
- Must be referred to the Pain Clinic for treatment
Exclusion Criteria
- History of surgery on the affected knee
- Evidence of untreated systemic infection or systemic immunocompromise
- Evidence of cutaneous infections near the study knee injection site
- Patients on warfarin with an INR > 3.0
- Patients on oral antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications will be excluded if they have documented evidence of renal insufficiency (GFR < 60)
- History of iodinated contrast allergy or significant reaction to corticosteroids or lidocaine

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation
